prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not allowing my gf (28) to be friends with co-worker(of 3+ years) anymore for calling one of their co-workers her "boyfriend"?
A little background, me and my gf live together (3 Months now) but have been on and off for 4 years. She's been friends with this girl for 3+ years. My gf told me straight up that this guy (let's call him Sam from now on) Sam doesn't talk too anyone at their job (plenty of male female associates). But, since he has worked there he "waves" at my gf and is the only person at their job he kinda talks to. I was ok with that. I trusted her since she brought it up. 

I posted yesterday that we go through each other's phones. Well she deleted a few message. Most were innocent "what are you girls wearing tomorrow?". How I know you ask? Well she has a Fitbit and while she deletes her text on her phone her Fitbit takes longer to delete them. (this isn't the point of this post please don't focus or make your decision based off this). But I used the knowledge that she erased messages (she doesn't know her fitbit is betraying her) to let her tell me everything she deleted. Turns out that she deleted a message where her friend said something along the lines of "your boyfriend (Sam) was late to work last night" my gf told me that she ignored the message and moved the conversation on. I believe her because she is under the impression that I read it all (still thinks I hacked her phone when in reality she sank herself. I read one fitbit message).

After finding this out. I said "I don't want you to be friends with her anymore she doesn't respect me as your man and us as a couple". I know some people joke around and sometimes have innocent "work husband's". I'm not ok with either. I believe my gf should had told her friend that it's not ok to call another man that and I don't think her friend had a right to joke like that. 

Am I the asshole for not wanting her to keep that friend anymore? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to work through this. The user is asking whether the author of the situation is in the wrong for cutting off his girlfriend's friend because the friend called another coworker "boyfriend." 

First, I need to understand the key points here. The girlfriend has been friends with this coworker for over three years. The boyfriend is okay with the friendship initially because he's told that the coworker (Sam) doesn't talk to anyone else at work. Then, the boyfriend finds out that the friend referred to another coworker, Sam, as "boyfriend," which upsets him. The girlfriend had deleted messages, but the boyfriend found out through her Fitbit. He then tells her to stop being friends with the coworker because the friend doesn't respect him as her boyfriend.

So, the main issue is whether the boyfriend is being unreasonable. The friend's comment was a joke or maybe an innocent "work husband" situation, which the boyfriend is not okay with. The boyfriend's reaction is to end the friendship. 

I need to consider if the boyfriend overreacted. The friend called someone else "boyfriend," not the boyfriend himself. The girlfriend didn't engage with the message and seems to have ignored it. The boyfriend is using this as a reason to cut off the friendship. But does that make sense? The friend might not have realized it was an issue, and the girlfriend didn't address it with her friend. However, the boyfriend is feeling disrespected by the friend's joke.

On one hand, the boyfriend is standing up for his boundaries. He might feel that any reference to another man being called "boyfriend" is inappropriate. On the other hand, the friend's comment could be seen as a harmless joke in a workplace context. Ending the friendship over a single joke might be seen as too harsh. Also, the girlfriend's actions (deleting messages) and the boyfriend's method of finding out (checking Fitbit) might contribute to the tension, but the core issue is the friend's comment.

Is the boyfriend in the wrong? If the friend's comment was innocent and the girlfriend didn't take issue with it, then the boyfriend's reaction might be unwarranted. But if the boyfriend's boundaries are such that he doesn't allow any other man to be called boyfriend, even in a joking manner, then his reaction is based on his personal boundaries. However, cutting off a long-time friend over a minor issue could be seen as extreme. 

So, maybe the answer is that the author is in the wrong because the friend's comment might not be a valid reason to end the friendship. The boyfriend is being controlling by not allowing any such references, even if they're not directed at him. Alternatively, if the boyfriend's boundaries are clear and the friend crossed them, then it's justified. But given that the friend might not have known it was a problem and the girlfriend didn't address it, the boyfriend's reaction could be seen as overstepping. 

Hmm, I think the key here is whether the friend's comment was actually disrespectful. Since the friend was referring to another coworker and the girlfriend didn't take offense, the boyfriend's reaction might be based on his own insecurities rather than the friend's actual behavior. So, the answer might be A (the author is in the wrong) because he's being controlling and overreacting to a minor issue.
